Text_Numeracy: When I was 23 years old living in Northern California, my Mother who was currently recovering from breast cancer informed me that she also had a rare medication resistant strain of tuberculosis. She was in relatively good health despite her current cancer diagnosis. Doctors were a little surprised by this.  She had been going to Kaiser twice week during her chemotherapy to receive other medications. I urged my mother to get a TB skin test immediately, she formally declined until I could see if they had anyway to check vaccination or TB skin test history.  I immediately checked and she had only had one when she was 5 years old, 39 years ago.  She finally agreed to be tested.  She was notified 2 days later by the Kaiser nurse that both she and all her children, except for me, who she saw 5 days a week, that we are all TB positive.  My moth-er and I started the 9 month medication regime  the next week.  I had to take on a medication round pick-up schedule as well as get all the med's mixed in a schedule that would avoid losing any time with both of my college majors or going to work.
